div.p: Yeah I suppose it’s waking up in the morning whether I can do the job but I always get up, always go to work, like this morning I knew I had
to, you know, get up by 12 so I had to jump on the cycle machine, work my muscles, you know work my upper body, get my legs like loose
so I can walk yeah it’s a normal routine for me, people wouldn’t understand but it’s become so natural to me over the years that I don’t think about it
you know an hour’s training is nothing to me because it’s just normal routine. If I know that I’m going to have to confront somebody
that’s able-bodied then I engage my brain and think “right for a few seconds you’re going to try and walk normally”, a normal person won’t understand
but somebody with a disability would because they have that moment where they go “think, right, I’m going to work all my muscles and try and walk
normally" so what I do is think “right I’m going to go outside now and confront this young person and tell them he should leave the premises or
he’s on camera please leave the premises” but with a young person if you’re nice to them they’ll be nice to you back, if you talk down to them
you know they’re going to answer you back and start being aggressive so you just talk to them in a general manner like calmly and not
being intimidating and they’re quite nice, yeah, not one of them’s come back to me anyway and started calling me names or anything like that.
